text: [Music] hi I'm Shane Harris with the algebra cartridge extension system it's officially Azalea season azaleas are blooming and garden centers are full of the plants trees ready for you to go purchase them so what do you do with these a is once you've mostly bought them or you brought some home for the new landscape today we're going to show you how to plant those azaleas when it comes to site selection on your new zone you need to take a lot of time to look where you're going to want to put this particular plant does it need to be near the house does it need to be more of a natural area you want to give it room to grow azaleas prefer filtered Sun and afternoon shade in other words they would prefer morning Sun maybe more shade in the afternoon they will tolerate Sun but they can get very hot in the summer time also looking for an area that's going to be well-drained azaleas prefer well-drained soil but cannot have any winter feet so an area that provides filtered Sun may be under pine trees just a few hardwoods maybe an open area that gives a plenty of Sun in the morning and afternoon shade when it's hot this summer is gonna be ideal as it should be grouped together based on color or variety and spaced properly around three to four feet apart depending on their maturity size now let's put the Azalea in the ground the planting hole should be no deeper than the depth of the container it came in but at least twice is wide to allow the proper root development one common mistake is playing the azalea's too deep in the ground adjust the depth of the planting hole by adding more salt underneath the root ball or under the pot to get the correct height and depth remove the Isaiah from the container and massage and loosen up the roots along the root ball this allowed those fibrous roots to grow out properly in keeping you from being pot bound while in the ground a common horticultural saying with azaleas is plant them high and then ever die you want to be sure that the root ball was about one inch above the native soil level there's again if they're planted too deep they will not survive before adding the native soil back into the planting hole and around the Azalea it's a good idea to add a little bit organic matter into the native soil to have the best of both worlds common Sol amendments would include compost or fine pine bark or they're store-bought soil amendment almost finished let's add the native soil and organic matter mixture back around the Azalea gently pushing it on east side and pressing downward so that root ball is covered and all air pockets are removed be sure not to bury the plant above the top of the root ball gently spread it out and firming the soil with your hands now add a layer of mulch around the plan choices could be pine straw or even pine bark this is very critical for the first year of the Azalea as it will lose moisture since its roots are not fully established this is very critical the first year to maintain that moisture in order to can survive the hot summers the last step is to give the Azalea drink of water you will want to water the Azalea at least once a week depending on the amount of rainfall and how hot the summers may be again spring planted azaleas will need at least one year for those roots to get well-established so again be sure to water them throughout the year azaleas are one of our prized Suns and landscape plants because they last so many years for more information on azaleas and other home and garden information visit us online at Asus dot edu or contact your local County Extension Office
